title: Relief of a Queen or Goddess
description:
Fragment of a limestone "sculptor's model" in form of rectangle with a relief on the two larger faces. Obverse, standing figure of Psamtik I (incomplete) with staff and, at right, his nomen in raised relief. Reverse, standing goddess wearing vulture headdress.
Condition: Poor. Major portion of figure of king missing. Large break on figure of goddess. Numerous minor chips.
section: The Third Intermediate Period & the Beginning of the Late Period

museum_location.name: 19th Dynasty to Roman Period, Martha A. and Robert S. Rubin Gallery, 3rd Floor

completeness.name: Best
completeness.description: All data has been vetted. Objects generally have quality photos and descriptions.

labels.content: Objects like this have long been regarded as trial pieces used by artists to sketch or carve drafts for larger works, a practice known from as early as the Old Kingdom. It has recently been argued, however, that the artists of Dynasty XXVI made objects similar in appearance whose purpose was that of votives offered at the cult places of the dynasty's kings. Perhaps some such objects served both purposes. The vulture headdress shown here is characteristic of queens, certain goddesses, and holders of the office of God's Wife of Amun, the celibate priestesses attached to the cult of Amun at Karnak.

collections.name: Egyptian, Classical, Ancient Near Eastern Art
